questions.question: How long have snakes been roaming the Earth?
What characteristics do all snakes share?
questions.d: They are both carnivores and cold-blooded

questions.question: How snakes hear?
questions.d: They don't use their ears at all

questions.question: What unique vision ability do boas and pythons possess?
How does a snake smell?
questions.d: Both through its nose and its tongues

questions.question: Where are Jacobson's organs located in snakes?
Snakes have very similar internal organs compared to humans. Snakes, however; lack the following:
Snakes have different shaped lungs than humans. What do snakes have?
What's true about two-headed snakes?
questions.b: They rarely survive in the wild

questions.question: What substance covers a snake's skin?
What snake doesn't have to have a mate to lay eggs?
Though invasive species can now be found in the Everglades, in which three continents are pythons (members of the family Pythonidae) found in the wild?
Pythons are held as some of the most dangerous snakes on earth, but are often confused with anacondas. Which of these is *not* a difference between pythons and anacondas?
questions.a: Pythons suffocate their prey, anacondas crush them
questions.b: Pythons lay eggs, anacondas give birth to live young
questions.c: Pythons grow longer, anacondas grow heavier
questions.d: Pythons generally spend less time in water than anacondas do

questions.question: Pythons are unable to chew their food, and so swallow prey whole. Which of these methods is most commonly demonstrated to help a python to swallow large prey?
questions.a: The python's stomach pressure is reduced, so prey is sucked in
questions.b: An extra set of upper teeth 'walk' along the prey
questions.c: The python holds its head up, so prey falls into its stomach
questions.d: Prey is pushed against a barrier and is forced down the python's throat

questions.question: Pythons, like many large constrictors, possess vestigial hind limbs. Whilst these 'spurs' serve no purpose in locomotion, how are they put to use by some male pythons?
Pythons tend to travel by the rectilinear method (in straight lines) when on land, as opposed to the concertina method (s-shaped movement). Why do large pythons tend not to use the concertina method?
questions.c: The scales on their backs are too rigid
